options: Complete a drug card yourself
Phone the Emergency Department and ask if they have it
Leave it on the jobs list for the on call doctor
Inform the bed manager that you will refuse to see the patient until there is a completed drug card
Ask a nurse to go down to the Emergency Department to look for it whilst you complete a clinical incident form
questions:
A patient is admitted to your ward from the Emergency Department. Their drug card is missing from the notes and you are due to finish work in around one hour.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
It seems sensible to first phone the Emergency Department to see if they have the card. This doesn't take much time and avoids duplication of work.

If the drug card cannot be found however then it should be completed. There is still one hour left before you finish so time should be available to do this.

Asking a nurse to leave the ward to look for it is a poor option. It is not their job, they will be busy on the ward and it is unlikely that he/she would find it. Whilst a clinical incident form could be completed if this event reoccurred frequently your time would be better spent rewriting the drug card.

Leaving it on the jobs list for the on-call doctor is a very poor option. This may delay the patient receiving medication. They will know very little about the patient and it is possible errors may be made.

The worst option is D. Refusing to see and treat a patient is clearly unprofessional and potentially dangerous.

options: Offer to discuss this with Amy somewhere more private
Offer to contact a colleague on the ward for an update on Amy's girlfriend
Advise Amy to speak to her educational supervisor
Speak to Amy's educational supervisor
Advise Amy to speak to her consultant regarding time off
Signpost Amy towards counselling services
Suggest to Amy that a course of sleeping tablets may help
Advise Amy to see her GP
questions:
Dave, a foundation doctor on the respiratory ward, notices that his fellow junior doctor Amy appears subdued and approaches her. Amy explains that her girlfriend is very unwell and has been admitted to the hospital. As a result, Amy is struggling to sleep and feels worried about safely managing her upcoming on-call shifts in 2 days' time.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question concerns both duty of care towards patients, but also duty of care and compassion towards a colleague. The most important immediate two actions are to advise Amy to speak to her consultant regarding time off, given that she does not feel that she could safely manage her on-call shift, and for her to speak to her educational supervisor, given that they look after trainees' pastoral care. Also appropriate would be to offer to discuss the matter with Amy somewhere more privately, for instance off the ward, where she may feel more comfortable in opening up about the current situation.

Dave should not contact Amy's educational supervisor himself at this stage - Amy has not yet done so, and so this should be done first. Whilst advising Amy to see her GP would be beneficial, and that a course of sleeping tablets may help, these do not address the immediate concern of patient safety, with regards to her upcoming on-call shift. Similarly, signposting Amy towards counselling services is a useful step, but again does not address the immediate patient safety issue.

title: GMC: Leadership and management for all doctors - Working with colleagues
body:
As with all aspects of medicine, the fundamental principle remains the same; make the patient your first concern. The purpose of this guidance is to allow the effective functioning of the clinical team to allow patient care to be done safely and smoothly, to the highest standards.

Leadership

The recommendations on leadership emphasise the importance of working within a multidisciplinary team. They specifically mention that other team members in leadership positions must be respected. This respect for non-medical staff in leadership roles is important.

For example, respecting the advice and leadership of an infection control nurse with regard to hand hygiene is important in making patients are protected from iatrogenic pathogen spread.

Respect for colleagues

If a colleague feels like they are not respected and not valued they may not feel able to speak up if they have concerns which may be relevant to patient safety. This is particularly important for junior and non-medical staff, and so it especially important to respect and value their skills and contribution to the team.

Additionally there is both a legal and moral responsibility to ensure that your colleagues have a safe and fair workplace. All doctors are responsible for facilitating this not only to avoid unpleasant behaviour themselves, but also by challenging others who act in a bullying or discriminatory manner. This is important both to comply with laws and policies on equality and diversity, but also to ensure patient safety as bullying and harassment will impair team cohesion and communication.


Communication within and between teams

The key message from this part of the guidance is that it is important that it is clear who is responsible for communicating what information both within members of the team, to other teams, and also to patients and carers. Mistakes are often made when team members assume that someone else will have passed on the relevant information and no one ends up doing it. Therefore whenever there is any doubt about whose job it is to pass on certain information, it is obligatory to check.

For example, if you expect that the nursing staff would have told you about any allergies the patient has, before prescribing it would be important to confirm with them that they have handed over all the relevant information.

Also it is important that teams cooperate more generally, including by having handovers. Proactive steps must be taken to clarify responsibilities and improve communication.

Responsibility and accountability

The most important duty of a doctor is to the dignity, safety and care of their patients. Again, it is important for doctors to ensure that it is clear exactly which staff members have which responsibilities, to ensure that these do not 'fall between the cracks' and get missed.

It is also important that you make these responsibilities clear to any staff in a team that you are leading.

When mistakes happen, it's often the result of system problems. For example it could be under-staffing putting decision making under higher strain, causing more mistakes. This happened in the Bawa-Garba case, the tragic death of a child from unrecognised sepsis on a day where a single doctor was trying to cover multiple wards.

Consequently, it is also the responsibility of doctors to engage in setting up and maintaining systems to make sure that risks are appropriately assessed and managed. Doctors are just as accountable for advice they give as a member of a decision making body, as they are for any other medical advice they offer.

options: Review the prescription sheet to check for errors
Discipline the nurse for giving too much medication
Stop the patient from taking the medication
Speak to the nurse who dispensed the medication to see why the patient has more
Respect the patient's autonomous decision to take more medication
questions:
You are a junior doctor on a care of the elderly ward. You see an elderly patient with dementia taking his morning medication. However, you notice that he has double the amount of a particular medication than you prescribed.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario places patient safety in jeopardy. The most important and first action that needs to be taken is to prevent the patient from taking the medication (C). Depending on the medication, taking too much could be dangerous, meaning preventing the patient from doing so is protecting patient safety. Once this is done, looking for the cause of the incident takes precedent.

Reviewing the prescription sheet to check for errors (A) is the next best option as it will help to identify whether there is an error on the prescription sheet, leading to the nurse dispensing too much medication.

Speaking to the nurse (D) is an important to both find out why the problem occurred and inform him/her of the error. The nurse may have some questions about whether the next dose should be given as normal, for example.

Discipling the nurse for giving too much medication (B) is an incorrect response. Firstly, It is unclear whether this incident has occurred due to a fault on the nurse's behalf, and secondly, it is not appropriate, or acceptable, for a nurse to be disciplined by a doctor.

Respecting the patient's autonomous decision to take more medication (E) is inappropriate. The patient has dementia and could likely have forgotten how many medications he takes, and the doses for each. This option places patient safety at risk.

options: Go ahead and ensure you delete the photo after the procedure
Phone the patients wife and ask her if it is okay to take a photo
Explain there is no consent for a photo to the consultant and that you can't proceed
Ask the medical student to do it instead
Phone medical imaging and ask them to take a photo in theatre
questions:
A consultant tells you to take some photos of a patient's nose in theatre on your mobile phone to write up as a case report. The patient is having an operation for a nasal tumour and taking a picture would result in some of his face being visible. You know that the patient has not consented to this as you were there for the consent process.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The most professional way to deal with this is to remind the consultant that the patient didn't consent to medical imaging (3). If you medical imaging take photos then this is still without consent but at least the images are stored securely (5). Taking the photos on your phone puts you at risk, particularly if the photos are automatically uploaded to online storage (1). The wife has no legal role in consenting for this patient (2) however it is even worse to pass the burden onto a medical student (4).

options: Give her a copy of the GMC guidance relating to patient confidentiality
Ask her to wait until her father is back so that you can ask his permission to speak to her
Say that the scan showed something, but give no further details
Tell her the results
Suggest that she speaks to her father about the results
questions:
You are an ST1 doctor on a stroke ward. One of your patients has had a recent CT scan which showed a brain tumour. The patient has been informed. The patient's daughter arrives whilst the patient is having a further scan and asks you about the results of her father's scan.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC publication, 'Confidentiality,' states that, 'You should establish with the patient the information they want you to share, who with, and in what circumstances.'
GMC 'Confidentiality,' paragraph 64, GMC guidance 2009.

Option B allows the patient to decide what information should be given to his daughter, as does option E, although this is less appropriate as it may to suggest to the patient's daughter that there is something that her father is not telling her.

Option A may sound good but is not the best way to handle what is likely an emotionally stressful time for her.

Of the two worst options, option C is better as it gives less specific information away than option D.

options: Complete a clinical incident form
Inform the consultant who is on-call for surgery
Move the patient to a different ward
Put a line through the signatures to prevent them from being used
Inform the consultant who is responsible for the patients
Refuse to prescribe fluids for the patient given what has happened
Tell the patient what has happened
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in General Surgery. Whilst on-call you are reviewing a post-op patient on the colorectal ward. On looking at the drug card you notice that the day F1 doctor has pre-signed the fluids prescription chart, leaving blank the type of fluid and additives. On discussing this with the nurses they inform you this is common and say it allows them to adjust the fluid and additives based on U&E results.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The rules governing the prescription of fluids are no different from those relating to drugs. Only those who are qualified to prescribe should make decisions about fluid type, additives or infusion rates. By pre-signing the prescription chart the F1 doctor has potentially exposed the patient to harm from the incorrect fluids being prescribed.

The first-step would be put a line through the signatures to prevent them from being used. The most appropriate person to contact is the consultant who is responsible for the patients. The seriousness of the situation also warrants a clinical incident form.

Telling the patient immediately is likely to alarm them in the post-op period as is moving them to a different ward. Refusing to prescribe fluids simply punishes the patient and is a poor response.

questions:
You have been involved in a patient's care for the past week and he is now fit for discharge. As he is leaving he hands you a £100 cheque insisting that you take it for taking such great care of him.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
E is the best option as it is polite but sticks to GMC guidance on accepting gifts.

Option A avoids accepting the gift but may appear rude and doesn't acknowledge the spirit in which the gift was likely intended.

Option D avoids it being a personal gift but a Christmas party fund is not the best suggestion. A related charity may be a better suggestion.

Option C is unprofessional, essentially negotiating an 'acceptable' amount.

Option B is the worst option.

options: Speak to Dr Smith privately about missed deadlines, offer support and suggest workload management strategies
Immediately escalate to your supervising consultant and request intervention
Take over Dr Smith’s tasks to ensure that deadlines are met, even if it means working additional hours
Discuss the issue with the entire team during a meeting, highlighting how Dr Smith’s delays are affecting the project
Document instances of missed deadlines and increased workload and escalate to the human resources department
Offer to work with Dr Smith to help prioritise tasks and manage time collaboratively
Ignore the issue, focusing instead on your own tasks and allowing the project timeline to be adjusted as necessary
Suggest a reallocation of tasks within the team to balance the workload more fairly and reduce the impact of Dr Smith’s delays
Encourage Dr Smith to attend time management workshops or training sessions to improve their efficiency
Make Dr Smith the team leader to oversee the audit project and ensure all team members meet their deadlines
questions:
You are a foundation doctor working in a team of four on an audit to improve patient safety. One of your colleagues, Dr Smith, consistently fails to meet deadlines, which causes delays and increases the workload for the rest of the team. The audit results are due in two weeks, and the team is under significant pressure.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Most appropriate:

Speak to Dr Smith privately about missed deadlines, offer support, and suggest workload management strategies is appropriate. Addressing the issue directly with Dr Smith in a private and supportive manner is a professional approach. It allows for an open conversation about the challenges and offers practical solutions to improve performance.

Offer to work with Dr Smith to help prioritise tasks and manage time collaboratively is appropriate. Collaborating with Dr Smith can help address the root cause of the delays and foster a supportive team environment. This approach can also help Dr Smith improve time management skills.

Suggest a reallocation of tasks within the team to balance the workload more fairly and reduce the impact of Dr Smith’s delays is appropriate. Reallocating tasks can help manage the immediate pressure on the team and ensure that deadlines are met. This approach addresses the workload distribution issue without singling out Dr Smith.

Least appropriate:

Immediately escalate to your supervising consultant and request intervention to address Dr Smith’s performance is not appropriate. Escalating the issue immediately might be premature. It is better to try resolving the issue with Dr Smith and within the team first before involving a supervisor.

Take over Dr Smith’s tasks to ensure that deadlines are met, even if it means working additional hours is not appropriate. Taking over Dr Smith’s tasks may temporarily solve the problem but is not sustainable and does not address the underlying issue. It also risks burnout.

Discuss the issue with the entire team during a meeting, highlighting how Dr Smith’s delays are affecting the project is not appropriate. Publicly addressing the issue could be embarrassing for Dr Smith and might create tension within the team. Private discussion is more appropriate initially.

Document instances of missed deadlines and increased workload and escalate to the human resources (HR) department is not appropriate. Escalating to HR should be a last resort after other measures have failed. It is important to try resolving the issue within the team first.

Ignore the issue, focusing instead on your own tasks and allowing the project timeline to be adjusted as necessary is not appropriate. Ignoring the issue is not a viable solution as it impacts the team and project deadlines.

Encourage Dr Smith to attend time management workshops or training sessions to improve their efficiency is not appropriate. While training can be helpful, it may not provide an immediate solution to the pressing deadline issue. It can be considered as a long-term solution.

Make Dr Smith the team leader to oversee the audit project and ensure all team members meet their deadlines is inappropriate. Given Dr Smith's difficulty with deadlines, making them the team leader is unlikely to resolve the issue and could potentially exacerbate it.

title: GMC: leadership and management guidance
body:
1. General Principles
  • Medical professionalism includes leadership, supervision, and service improvement
  • Applies to all doctors, PAs, and AAs — not just those in formal management roles
  • Patient safety, dignity, and care quality are always the top priority

2. Teamwork & Communication
  • Work respectfully in multidisciplinary teams
  • Share info clearly with colleagues, especially during handovers
  • Don’t assume others will pass on critical information
  • Encourage collaboration and address poor communication or unclear roles

3. Raising Concerns
  • Act when patient safety is at risk
  • Follow local protocols for whistleblowing
  • You remain accountable even in non-clinical or managerial roles

4. Reflective Practice & Appraisal
  • Regularly reflect on your own practice and seek feedback
  • Take part in appraisals and revalidation
  • Use audit and governance systems to improve performance

5. Supervision & Mentoring
  • Participate in induction and mentoring schemes
  • Support and supervise junior colleagues appropriately
  • Know your limits and ask for help when needed

6. Teaching & Training
  • Be a positive role model
  • If teaching formally, ensure you're trained and competent
  • Promote inclusive, supportive learning environments

7. Equality & Professional Conduct
  • Treat colleagues fairly; no bullying, harassment, or discrimination
  • Respect and follow EDI policies in recruitment and assessments
  • Support colleagues with health/performance issues; refer if serious concern

8. Managing Resources
  • Use NHS resources wisely; understand financial structures relevant to your role
  • Take part in decisions about service planning, budgets, and priorities
  • Be transparent and fair when allocating treatments under limited resources

9. Conflicts of Interest
  • Declare personal/financial interests
  • Ensure resources and decisions are used for intended, patient-centred purposes
  • Monitor systems for fairness, transparency, and accountability

options: Change prescription to regular dose
Speak to the ward pharmacist
Give the requested dose
Contact registrar and discuss
Contact the consultant and discuss the prescription
questions:
You are a junior doctor on a cardiology ward. You consultant has left a message requesting that you prescribe a medication for a patient who was newly admitted during the night. The medication that he requests prescribed is above the usual dose for this particular medication, although you are aware that higher doses can be used in some patients. Your consultant is currently working away from the hospital and you do not expect to see him today.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
As you are not fully confident over the reason for the increased dose, this needs to be confirmed prior to you prescribing it. The most appropriate person to confirm this is the person who asked you to prescribe the medication in the first place, your consultant. Therefore, contacting your consultant to discuss the prescription (E) is the most appropriate response to this scenario. The fact that he is away from the hospital for the day does not affect your response.

Alternate sources of confirmation for the higher doses could be obtained through your registrar (E or the ward pharmacist (B). Your registrar would likely know the indications for the increased dose of medication.

Prescribing the requested dose without checking (C) is a poor option, but not as bad as changing the dose. There may be reasons why the consultant has chosen a particular dose. Changing this without checking (A) is potentially putting the patient at risk.

options: Have a quiet word with the consultant after the ward round to avoid any embarrassment and stop simvastatin for the duration of the clarithromycin therapy
Remind the consultant that clarithromycin should not be coprescribed with simvastation
Ask the consultant if she'd like the simvastatin to be stopped for the duration of the clarithromycin therapy
Don't say anything but stop simvastatin for the duration of the clarithromycin therapy
Prescribe clarithromycin as requested and make no further changes to the drug chart
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a consultant ward round. Your team is reviewing a patient who was admitted last night with pneumonia. The patient was initially given intravenous antibiotics but the consultant feels they can be stepped down to tablets. As the patient is allergic to penicillin she asks for clarithromycin 500mg bd to prescribed. You notice on the drug chart that the patient takes simvastatin and remember from your medical training that these medications should not be taken concurrently.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Prescribing marcolides such as clarithromycin can significantly increase the risk of rhabdomyolysis in patients taking statins. It is a common drug interaction in hospitals and should be avoided.

There are a number of explanations for why the consultant hasn't said anything:
  • she is not aware that the patient is taking a statin
  • she presumes you are aware that statins should be stopped in such a scenario
  • she has temporarily forgotten about the interaction

It is therefore important to be measured in your response to such a scenario. Option C is the best response as it does not jump to any conclusions as to why the consultant hasn't asked you to stop the statin.

Option B is good as it brings up the potential interaction but is slightly more confrontational and presumes that the consultant has forgotten.

Option A also ensures that the issue is dealt with but again rather presumes that the consultant has forgotten. It is also against the GMC's desire to have an open, patient-safety focused clinical environment. All clinicians, regardless of seniority, should be open about any potential mistakes or omissions.

Option D has merit as it prevents the drug interaction from occuring but it does nothing to stop similar episodes happening in the future. What if the consultant often doesn't check the drug chart before prescribing and the next junior doctor isn't as vigilant as you?

Option E is the worse response as it potentially allows the drug interaction to take place.
